author: pipermerriam
content:
(Shower Thoughts)...

<@!689161464829050960> posting this here because it might be of generic interest as a tool for DiscV5 infrastructure, but I'm thinking about it in the context of the <#796057759858425866> discussions around how to send our proofs via a POKE when they exceed the UDP packet size.

Bittorrent defines the "uTorrent Transport Protocol" here:  https://www.bittorrent.org/beps/bep_0029.html

I've only read through the spec once, but my understanding is that it provides an abstracted "stream" protocol on top of UDP that also has the nice property of built-in congestion control.  After reading the spec it seems well suited for a DiscV5 sub-protocol that could be used by other subprotocols to transfer data that exceeds the UDP packet size.  A rough sketch of how this would work is:

- There is data that needs to be transferred that exceeds the UDP packet size.  A unique connection identifier is generated and sent so that both parties know it.
- A new "stream" is opened on the `discv5-utp` subprotocol, loosely following the spec layed out in BEP29 using the connection identifier
- The stream is used until it is closed...
